msItem.rubric: Name of St. Mary; name of the commissioner; a few lines, or groups of lines, alternating with black lines, on the incipit (or incipit page) of the texts; the numbers and title of the miracles in Text I-2; the initial words of some subsections; the word haleluya on fol. 163vb; Ethiopic numerals and sometimes their elements; elements of punctuation signs and of coronis; crux ansata with coronis on fol. 182r.

msItem.note: - Some folios are missing and many are misplaced.

For the reconstruction of the texts, the following Mss., containing almost the same texts or some of them, have been consulted and compared withAQG-005: Orient. 686 (cp. WrBriMus 167, no. 257), Orient.687-688(cp. WrBriMus 167, no. 257). The Catalague of Wright (WrBriMus) has been used as reference for some of the saints names and the commemoration dates.
- On fol. 270va-vb, after Text I-36, a long Subscriptio concludes the entire work:
[fol. 270va] ተፈጸመ፡ በዝየ፡ ገድሎሙ፡ ለቅዱሳን፡ ሰማዕት፡ እለ፡ ተሣየጡ፡ በሞት፡ ሕይወት፨ ... ወአጽሐፊሁሰ፡ ለዝንቱ፡ መጽሓፍ፡ አቡነ፡ <…> ረባን፡ አበ፡ መነኮሳት፡ ... [fol. 270vb] ምስለ፡ ጸሓፊሁ፡ ሳሙኤል፡ … ወምስለ፡ አኃው፡ ዘደብረ፡<…> ….

The note mentions the commissioner, whose name here is erased. He must be the afore mentioned ʾabunä Ṗeṭros who is mentioned in the exhortations throughout the Ms. In the subscriptio, after the erasure there are the titles räban (“master”; s. also on fol. 262rb) and ʾabä mänäkosat (“the head of the monks”). They are probably referred to Filǝṗṗos (s. above), the ʾabunä Ṗeṭros' "father". At the end of the note, there is the mention of the scribe Samuʾel, to whom some of the exhortations are dedicated, and of the "brothers of the däbr" from where most probably also the commissioner and the scribe come.

- Some of the gädl (i.e. I-1, I-2, I-10, I-13, I-14, I-15, I-17, I-21, I-22, I-23, I-27, I-28 ) end with a final note with the concluding formula “ተፈጸመ፡ (or ተፈጸመ፡ ብዝየ፡) ገድሉ፡…” of the text, followed sometimes by the commemoration dates of the saints to whom the text is dedicated, or also by supplication formulas.

These final notes are alone or are followed by exhortation notes, short or extended, (ጸልዩ፡ ለዘ…) for the commissioner (sometimes also for his children, or for the children of his place), for the scribe, the reader, the translator of the gädl, and for the ones who believe and make the “täzkar” of the saints to whom the gädl is dedicated. These exhortations are after the majority of the texts (i.e. I-1, I-2 I-3 I-4 I-5, I-6 I-8, I-9, I-10 I-11, I-12, I-13, I-16, I-17, I-18, I-19, I-20, I-21, I-23, I-24, I-25, I-27, I-29, I-30, I-31, I-32, I-33, I-34, I-35).

- About the scribe and the mention of his name in the above mentioned exhortation notes, s. above in “short content”. On fol. 23rb, in the exhortation at the end of Text I-2, the name of the scribe has been erased.

- In the exhortation notes on fols. 89rb, 91ra, 98rb, 114rb, 120ra, 127rb, respectively at the end of Texts I-12, I-13, I-11, I-14, I-17, I-18, the commissioner, ʾAbunä Ṗeṭros, is said to be “lover of the Gädlä sämaˤtat” (መፍቀሬ፡ ገድሎሙ፡ ለሰማዕታት).
On fol. 127rb, it is also written that he is the “master of the ‘temple’” (መምህረ፡ አላዳስ).
On fols. 41vb,150va, he is mentioned as: ʾabunä Ṗeṭros zä-Däbrä Mämhǝr.
About the mention of the commissioner on the other folios, s. above in “short content”.
Details on some texts:
- Text I-4. The miracles are not numbered.

- Text I-25. On fol. 187va, at the end of the text, as the month of the commemoration date for the martyrs ʾArǝrinosofis, Peter and ʾƎskǝryon, is written Ṗäsini (ጰሲኒ), instead of the Ethiopian name ሰኔ.

Comparing the same text in, e.g., Orient. 686, the month at the same passage is written as Ṗahin/Ṗaḥin (ጳሂን/ጳሒን). Ṗaḥin (c. Dillmann Lexicon, p. 1251) is the Ethiopian name for Paōni, the 10th month of the Coptic Calendar, which corresponds to the Ethiopian month Säne.

In the text ofAQG-005, Ṗäsini might appear phonetically more similar to the 9th month (in Sahidic) of the Coptic calendar, i.e. Pašons (s. CE II, 439). It also look as if it is an assimilation (scribe mistake?) of ጰ (from the Coptic month) and ሲኒ (from ሰኔ).
At the left margin of the Coptic month, probably as cue for the rubricator, is annotated the letter ግ.

- Text I-27. On fol. 222rb, the text ends with the colophon of the work with the mention of Metropolitan ʾAbba Sälama (Metropolitan from 1350 or 1348; cp. EAE IV, 488-89) and its work of translation from Arabic into Gǝˤǝz.

At the end of the colophon, the date “1079 from the ‘Years of the Martyrs’ (እመዋዕለ፡ ሰማዕት)” is indicated. It is not clear if it refers to the year when ʾAbba Sälama translated the text. According to the “Chronologie” of Chaine, this date, 1079 E.M.D., should corresponds to 1363 A.D. (cp. ChChron, 161).

- Text I-16. On fol. 196va, at the end of text, as month of the commemoration date of the martyr ʾAtnasewos, it is given the month ʾIyolyu (ኢዮልዩ) and after it Ḥamle, mentioned as the correspondent month in Gǝˤǝz. ʾIyolyu appears phonetically very similar to “Iulius”, the Latin name for the month July.

- Text I-30. On fol. 236ra, at the end of text, as month of the commemoration date of the martyr Maccabees and her 7 sons, it is written ʾAwgusṭos (አውግስጦስ). This name is mentioned as month in the byzantine calendar (በአውራኅ፡ ሮሜ); the same is on fol. 273rb in Orient. 686.

supportDesc.condition: The front board is broken and the back is missing; the original sewing is for the most part missing. The Ms. has been wrongly rearranged and resewn. Many fols. are missing and some are misplaced. Many fols. are affected by humidity and stained with dirt; some parts of text are illegible (e.g., fols. 177rb, 177ra, 267va, 268rb). The bottom part of fols. 242-268 seems damaged by rodents. Fol. 1 is damaged. Cuts repaired, e.g., on fols. 67, 149, 174, 221. Some fols. seem to have been cut at the bottom: e.g., fols. 123, 128, 133, 134.

layout.ab: the number of the lines is very irregular
The upper line is written below the ruling (above on many fols., e.g. 1-59, 65, 74-81, 107-112, 115r-119r, 201-208).
The bottom line is written above the ruling.
One or two upper ruled lines were not used by the scribe on fols. 98r, 114r, 227r, 234v, 235r.

handDesc.handNote: Irregular Black; red (vivid vermillion). SamuʾelSamuʾel is mentioned as the scribe in the exhortation after Texts I-27 (fol. 222rb), I-33 (fol. 254rb), I-34 (fol. 267vb) and in the subscriptio at the end of Text I-36 (fol. 271vb). In the exhortation on fol. 176rb, the name of Samuʾel has been written over erasure (not sure if later).Second half of 15th century (?)
The handwriting is characterized by thick strokes and right-sloping letters. It is possible that several hands were involved in writing (cp. fols. 25v-26r).
Some peculiar features:
Letters:
- ጵ has the 6th order marker set up on the vertical stroke at the top, oriented to the left (e.g., fols. 67vb l.18, 152rb l.1)
- ሎ has the 7th order marker attached directly at the body of the letter, without linking line (e.g., fol. 13rb l.4)
- the upper horizontal strokes of መ and ሠ, in the 1st order, are slanted to the left

- the 6th order marker of the letter የ has a very short and downwards oriented left part, going down below the ruling (e.g., fols. 209ra l.4, 225va l.14); in the 4th order, the marker is short as well and diagonal (e.g., fols. 229va l.11, l.16, 98rb l.11)
- ኴ has the loop marking the 5th order open (fol. 225ra l.1, l.8).
Numbers:
- the numbers are mostly written without dashes
- ፬ is triangular and downwards oriented (e.g., fol. 23ra)
- ፮ is with the loop open, looking like “compressed” ፯ (e.g., fol. 35vb)
- ፪ has the loops closed, not separated
- ፼ has the ligature (e.g., fol. 18rb).
Punctuation:

- Crux ansata and coronis (together or separated) are in the margins of some texts: on fol. 182r, the crux ansata with coronis marking the beginning; on fols. 23r, 57v, 120r, 139v, the coronis used as caesura
- sentence dividers are accompanied by the paragraph signs (throughout the Ms.).
Other:
- The word እግዚአብሔር is usually written እግዚኣብሐር (the second አ in the 4th order). The same word sometimes is written with the ligature (e.g., fol. 113rb l.28)
- the size of the letters and columns (s., e.g., fols. 25v-26r).

Fols. 13v, 23v, 32r, 36r, 50r, 54r, 58r, 72v, 82v, 89v, 91v, 98v, 113v, 114va, 127v, 133vb, 140ra, 150vb, 168r, 176v, 188r, 197r, 202r, 223r, 229r, 258r, 262v (incipit or incipit pages of Texts I-2, I-3, I-4, I-5, I-7, I-8, I-9, I-11, I-12, I-13, I-10, I-14, I-16 I-17, I-19, I-20, I-21, I-22, I-23, I-24, I-26, I-27; I-28, I-29, I-30, I-35, I-32): coloured (red, green, blue, yellow, white), ornamental band, with three vertical extensions reaching the middle of the page; the horizontal band reaches the top of the page; interlaces, crosses.

Fol. 42r (incipit page of Text I-6): elaborate, coloured (red, green, yellow, white), ornamental band with three vertical extensions reaching the bottom of the page; the horizontal band extends to the top of the page; interlaces, crosses, geometric motifs.
Fols. 121ra, 182rb, 236rb, 263vb, 270r (incipits or incipit page of Texts I-18, I-25, I-31, I-33, I-36): simple, coloured (red, blue, yellow, white) ornamental band; interlaces.

Fol. 253v: Ownership note. Fol. 253v: ዝመጽሐፍ፡ ዘአድ፡ ቋልቋል፡ ዘቅዱስ፡ ጊዮርጊስ፡ ዘተሳየጦ፡ በወርቁ፡ ክፍ[sic] ዘአቡነ፡ [ገብረ፡ክር]ስቶስ፡
The note, partly unclear and possibly unfinished, has been written within the frame of the ornamental cross (above left side). The note states that the book is property of the church of ʿAddi Qolqwal Giyorgis (ʾAd Qwalqwal), purchased by ʾabunä Gäbrä Krǝstos. Additio 2 of AQG-003 is written in the same hand.

- The note ገድለ፡ ሰማዕታት፡ ብርእየ፡ ሥመሪ፡ is written in the bottom margin of fol. 51r, probably in a secondary hand. - The title ገድለ፡ ሰማዕ[sic] is written, in a secondary hand, at the edge of the bottom margin on fol. 73r. - Fol. 120vb: crude and recent note, after Text I-17, repeating the incipit of Text I-18 on fol. 121ra. - Cues for the rubricator (numerals) throughout the Ms. - Corrections (words or letters) written interlineally: fols. 58rb, 60va, 74ra, 135va. - Correction written over erasure: fol. 38ra. - Compressed script: fols. 35vb, 41va, 53vb, 89rb, 113rb, 263va. - Pen trial: fol. 222v. - Crude notes and drawings in pen or pencil in the margins and on the inner front board: e.g., fols. 12r, 18r, 31r, 32r, 57r, 75r, 137r, 143r, 202r.

Some of the quires are reinforced by parchment guards. On the front board possibly traces of leather cover. Recent threads for the sewing are visible on some fols. (e.g., between fols. 55v-56r and on fols. 122v, 123v, 125v, 144v).

origin.origDate: If we suppose that the Ms. was commissioned by ʾabunä Ṗeṭros from Däbrä Bizän (s. above), the date of its production may be collocated in the second half of the 15th century.

person.persName: ʾAbunä Ṗeṭros is mentioned as the commissioner in the subscriptio at the end of Text I-36 and in the exhortations at the end of the most texts. In many of them, his name is mentioned together with the name of his monastery (i.e. ʾabunä Ṗeṭros zä-Däbrä <…>), which is however always partly erased. On fol. 13rb (Text I-1) the last letter of the name is readable(ደብረ፡ <…>ን). On fols. 228vb, 254ra, 262rb, it is said that he is the son (disciple) of ʾabunä Filǝṗos, named the “righteous” (“ṣadǝq”, fol. 254rb) and the “teacher” (“räban”, fols. 262rb, 270va). Considering this date and the small clue on fol. 13rb, it might be possible suppose that the monastery of ʾabunä Ṗeṭros and where this Ms. was originated is Däbrä Bizän (in Eritrea). The founder of this monastery was the monk Filǝṗos (1322/23-1406; cp. EAE II, 15-17). On fol. 57vb, ʾabunä Ṗeṭros is mentioned as the abbot (ʾabä mǝnet) of his monastery. According to an additional note in a Bible Ms. from Däbrä Bizän, Ṗeṭros is mentioned as the 4th “mämhǝr” of the monastery, third successor of the founder Filǝṗos. His death is to be collocated between 1488/89 and 1491/92. His predecessor was Säräqä Bǝrhan (d. 1460/61 or 1457/58) (cp. Schneider, in AÉ 1978, 138-39).
As mentioned in Additio 2, the owner of the book is the church of ʿAddi Qolqwal Giyorgis.
